title: Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle
formal_statement: For any quantum state, the product of the standard deviations of two non-commuting observables (e.g., position x and momentum p) satisfies: Delta_x * Delta_p >= hbar/2, where hbar is the reduced Planck constant.
plain_language: Certain pairs of physical properties, like position and momentum, cannot both be measured with arbitrary precision simultaneously. The more precisely you know one, the less precisely you can know the other.
assumptions_scope: Applies to fundamental quantum systems, not macroscopic objects
evidence_basis: Derived from the canonical commutation relations in quantum mechanics (Heisenberg 1927, Kennard 1927). The uncertainty principle is a fundamental consequence of wave-particle duality and the mathematical structure of quantum theory.
typical_traps: Assuming arbitrary precision is achievable for complementary observables simultaneously
Treating uncertainty as purely measurement error (it's intrinsic to quantum states)
Confusing Heisenberg uncertainty with classical measurement limitations
Believing better instruments can overcome the principle

examples: Spin in same direction (Sz and Sz)
Multiple position measurements at different times
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Cannot access complementary information; limited to compatible measurements

examples: Design experiments that require only one observable precisely
Use statistical ensembles to characterize distributions
Optimize measurement for specific application (e.g., prioritize position)
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Must choose which observable matters more; complementary information remains uncertain

escape_hatches.description: Use weak measurements or conditional strategies
examples: Weak measurement (minimal disturbance but low information gain)
Quantum state tomography across many systems
Squeezed states (reduce uncertainty in one variable at expense of other)
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Requires many measurements or auxiliary systems; tradeoff persists but can be optimized

test_or_check: Identify if the claim requires simultaneous precise knowledge of non-commuting observables (position-momentum, energy-time, angular momentum components). If yes, flag as conflicting with uncertainty principle.
references: Heisenberg, W. (1927). Über den anschaulichen Inhalt der quantentheoretischen Kinematik und Mechanik. Zeitschrift für Physik, 43(3-4), 172-198.
Kennard, E. H. (1927). Zur Quantenmechanik einfacher Bewegungstypen. Zeitschrift für Physik, 44(4-5), 326-352.
notes: The uncertainty principle is often misunderstood as a limitation of measurement technology. It is actually a fundamental property of quantum states themselves, reflecting wave-like nature of matter.
